info: Company disclosed segment classifications and concentration risk metrics for major customers (Dell, Lenovo, HP) and operating units (Intel Foundry, Assembly & Test, Client Computing, Datacenter & AI, Network & Edge) with a uniform reported figure of 50863 across reporting periods from 2021 to 2024, indicating no variation in the disclosed numeric values.

The filing discloses customer concentration risk metrics, reporting net sales revenue for major customers—including Lenovo Group, HP Inc., and the three largest customers—at approximately $280 billion for 2024, $300 billion for 2023, and $310 billion for 2022, indicating a slight decline in recent year.

The filing lists numerous capital‑related grants, restructuring programs, litigation items and segment updates (NAND Memory, Client Computing, Datacenter & AI) for 2023‑2024, repeatedly citing an amount of 50,863.
The filing lists many business segments and debt instruments with associated dates, each showing the same numeric amount of 300000050863, but offers no further qualitative commentary.

The filing lists multiple senior notes and Oregon‑Arizona bond issuances, primarily showing $300,000 amounts for 2023 issues and $280,000 amounts for 2024 issues across various series and credit facilities.

The filing details fair value measurements for investment categories such as fixed income securities, repurchase agreements, corporate debt and government debt, indicating a decline in reported amounts from roughly 300000050863 as of Dec 2023 to about 280000050863 as of Dec 2024.
Fair value measurement disclosures for short‑term investments and equity securities show consistent reported amounts of 50,863 across multiple reporting periods (2021‑2024).

Intel’s 2024 Form 10‑K notes a market value of $132.4 billion and 4.33 billion shares outstanding, confirms its status as a large accelerated filer, and emphasizes forward‑looking plans and risks including its foundry and AI strategies, ongoing leadership transition, cessation of capital returns, and exposure to macro‑economic, geopolitical and supply‑chain uncertainties.

The filing outlines a broad set of material risks—including cybersecurity, IP litigation, talent retention, debt, currency, tax and catastrophic events—and notes the company has stopped returning capital to shareholders. Intel emphasizes its strategy centered on product competitiveness, open platforms, manufacturing scale, and talent, with a focus on expanding its x86 and xPU portfolio, AI initiatives, and building a foundry business. It highlights investments in geographically balanced manufacturing, use of 300 mm wafers with Intel 7, Intel 4 and Intel 3 process nodes, and a Smart Capital approach leveraging capacity investments, government incentives, strategic private capital (SCIP), and customer commitments.

Intel emphasizes investing in R&D and capital spending, suspending dividends and stock repurchases through 2026 to fund critical initiatives. It secured up to $7.9 billion under the CHIPS Act and up to $3 billion for Secure Enclave, expecting over $25 billion in capital offsets via partnerships. The company advanced its EUV lithography nodes (Intel 4, Intel 3) with significant performance‑per‑watt gains and launched new products across client, data‑center, GPU, edge, and AI accelerator portfolios, highlighting 70% higher core performance and 50% better power efficiency in the Arc B‑Series. Ongoing facility expansions in Ireland, Arizona, Ohio, and abroad aim to achieve “shell‑ahead” capacity, while divesting non‑core NAND and Optane businesses.

Intel secured up to $7.9 billion in CHIPS Act funding and up to $3 billion in Secure Enclave funding, expects over $25 billion of capital offsets through partnerships, and highlighted a 15% headcount reduction plan, a workforce of 108,900, and diversity metrics (women 27.9% globally, 18.3% senior leadership; under‑represented minorities 17.8% US staff, 8.7% US senior leadership). Revenue fell to $53.1 billion, down $1.1 billion (2%), while R&D spending hit $16.5 billion, capital investments $25.1 billion, cash from operations $8.3 billion and adjusted free cash flow was –$2.2 billion. Restructuring charges totaled $2.8 billion, with additional $3.3 billion non‑cash impairments and $3.1 billion goodwill impairments. Sustainability goals link bonuses to cutting 25,000 t CO₂e, reaching 95% renewable electricity, conserving 13.5 billion gallons of water, and achieving >90% construction‑waste recycling.

The company launched a 2024 Restructuring Plan targeting a ~15% headcount cut and a $2.8 billion restructuring charge, while recognizing $3.3 billion of non‑cash cost‑of‑sales impairments, $3.1 billion goodwill impairment and $9.9 billion tax valuation allowances. Segment results exclude $7.0 billion of restructuring and $9.9 billion tax charges. PC market is stabilizing, with over 200 million commercial PCs older than four years and a projected long‑term TAM of 300 million units, supported by the new Intel Core Ultra AI PC processor. Data Center and AI segments highlight launches of Xeon 6 processors, Gaudi 3 accelerators and ongoing AI accelerator development. Financial tables show total 2024 revenue of $48.9 billion, gross margin $25.1 billion (51%) and operating income $13.2 billion (27%).

Intel Products revenue modestly grew to $48.9 billion in 2024 (+$1.3 billion YoY) driven by a $1.0 billion increase in CCG and $0.182 billion rise in DCAI, while NEX added $68 million. Notebook sales rebounded (+12% volume) offset by lower desktop volume (-5%). Gross margin held near 49% and operating margin at 24% despite a $303 million decline in total cost of sales and a $267 million reduction in operating expenses. The company highlighted continued investment in Intel Foundry, targeting 2nm production in 2025 and pursuing third‑party foundry business to leverage scale.

Intel Foundry highlighted upcoming process technologies including Intel 18A with RibbonFET and PowerVia, Intel 3 EUV, Intel 7, Intel 16 and a collaborative 12nm node, and roadmap extension to Intel 14A, plus advanced packaging and the UCIe interconnect demonstrated in silicon 2023. Competitors remain TSMC, Samsung, GlobalFoundries, UMC and SMIC, with direct competition against TSMC and Samsung in advanced nodes. Foundry revenue fell to $17.5B in 2024, down $1.4B YoY, with intersegment revenue and external revenue also decreasing. Cost of sales rose sharply to $25.6B driven by non‑cash impairments and accelerated depreciation, while operating expenses increased to $5.4B due to higher process‑technology investment, resulting in an operating loss of $13.4B. The All‑Other segment (Altera, Mobileye, etc.) saw revenue decline to $3.8B in 2024, with Altera at $1.5B and Mobileye at $1.7B, reflecting reduced customer inventories. However, 2023 showed modest recovery in All‑Other revenue and profitability.

Revenue fell 2% to $53.1 billion in 2024, driven by lower all‑other and Foundry revenue, while gross margin dropped $4.4 billion (20%) due to $3.3 billion asset impairments, $922 million AI‑accelerator inventory charges and a higher unit‑cost mix. Cost of sales declined to $35.8 billion and operating expenses were flat at $2.1 billion, but total R&D and MG&A rose to $22.1 billion (up 2%). Restructuring charges surged to $6.97 billion, mainly employee severance $2.48 billion and asset impairments $3.63 billion. Capital investments in construction‑in‑progress grew to $50.4 billion. Net loss widened to $19.2 billion versus a $1.7 billion profit year‑over‑year, with diluted EPS of –$4.38.

The 2024 restructuring plan generated substantial charges, including $2.2 billion in employee severance, $294 million for other cost‑reduction actions and total restructuring and other charges of $6.97 billion. Litigation costs were $780 million, while a $1.2 billion benefit and $401 million fine plus a $353 million termination fee were recorded in 2023. Asset impairments totaled $3.1 billion in goodwill, $442 million for construction‑in‑progress, and $103 million for lease assets. Equity investment activity yielded a net gain of $242 million in 2024, driven by $715 million realized gains from sales, offset by unrealized losses of $218 million. Interest‑and‑other net was $226 million. The effective tax rate rose to 71.6% as a $8.023 billion provision was recorded against a pre‑tax loss of $11.21 billion. Liquidity remained strong with $22.062 billion in cash and short‑term investments and $50.011 billion total debt. Capital‑expenditure commitments for 2025 are $14.0 billion, plus $6.0 billion long‑term. Government incentives include up to $3.0 billion and a $7.9 billion award, of which $1.1 billion was received in 2024. The company issued $2.6 billion of senior notes, remarketed $438 million of other bonds, expanded its revolving credit facilities to $7.0 billion (5‑year) and $8.0 billion (364‑day) before amending the latter to $5.0 billion, and retains a $10.0 billion commercial‑paper authorization.

Liquidity management actions such as supplier payment term optimization, receivables sales and inventory adjustments supported cash flow in 2024, but the benefit may reverse. Operating cash flow fell sharply versus 2023, while capital expenditures remained high at roughly $24‑$26 billion. Financing cash provided modest inflows. The company highlighted intensified competition, especially in AI and foundry markets, and noted delays in fab expansions and higher R&D/CapEx risks.

Intel highlights ongoing high R&D spending ($16.5B in 2024) and significant capital intensity, while noting delayed fab expansions in multiple regions and risk‑laden foundry strategy. The company disclosed sizable non‑cash impairment and depreciation charges ($3.1B in Q3 2024), a $922M inventory write‑down for Gaudi AI accelerators, and a $755M penalty charge for Ireland construction delays. Persistent delays in advanced node rollouts and reliance on large upfront investments increase operating cost, margin pressure, and execution risk.

The company highlights material risks from fluctuating product demand, macro‑economic and geopolitical tensions, and supply‑chain constraints, including heavy reliance on overseas markets (76% of revenue outside the U.S., 29% from China) and single‑source suppliers such as ASML and TSMC. Margin pressure may arise if sales shift to lower‑margin products, as seen with the Intel Core Ultra 200V launch. Ongoing export‑control restrictions on China, trade disputes, and regional conflicts (Israel, Taiwan) could impair sales and operations. Recent product‑quality issues with 13th‑ and 14th‑gen desktop processors have impacted sales and may increase warranty costs, while the uncertain AI market adds demand volatility.

The company highlights significant product security and cyber vulnerability risks, including side‑channel exploits like Spectre and Meltdown, and notes challenges in timely mitigation, export restrictions, and third‑party dependencies. It also stresses exposure to IP litigation, citing recent injunctions and costly lawsuits, and acknowledges a $2.9 billion goodwill impairment charge related to Mobileye in Q3 2024. Additional concerns include liability insurance exclusions, data‑privacy liabilities, talent retention pressures, recent CEO turnover, and broader strategic‑transaction risks that could impact financial results.

The company highlights several material risks: recent senior leadership turnover with the CEO retiring in Dec 2024, ongoing strategic transaction uncertainties that previously led to a $2.9 billion goodwill impairment charge, high customer concentration (top three customers represent 45% of 2024 revenue), substantial debt levels ($51 billion of senior notes plus $10 billion commercial paper program and $15 billion credit facilities), suspension of dividends under the CHIPS Act, and exposure to government contract, currency, regulatory and environmental challenges.

The filing highlights heightened ESG and regulatory compliance risks, including new climate‑related laws, and ongoing cybersecurity threats despite no material incidents to date. It notes exposure to currency, interest‑rate and equity market risks, with potential adverse impacts on income before taxes and investment fair values. The company disclosed significant marketable and non‑marketable equity holdings and outlined a modest increase in interest expense if rates rise. Intel reported its owned and leased facility footprint (70 million sq ft total) and introduced new Intel Core Ultra and Xeon 6 processors with AI capabilities, while emphasizing continued marketing and brand initiatives. Approximately 92,000 registered shareholders were recorded as of early 2025.

Intel had about 92,000 registered common stock holders as of Jan 24 2025. The company’s $110 billion share‑repurchase authorization remains largely unused, with $7.2 billion still available and no repurchases in FY2024. Cumulative five‑year total shareholder return (TSR) assuming $100 invested shows Intel’s return fluctuating from $100 in 2019 to $80 in 2020, $90 in 2021, $48 in 2022, $123 in 2023 and $50 in 2024, indicating volatility relative to benchmark indices.

Intel disclosed engagements with Russian entities subject to sanctions (FSB and Positive Technologies) with no associated revenue, noted ongoing compliance under OFAC licenses; inventory valued at $12.2 billion (6.2% of assets) with significant judgment required; goodwill total $24.7 billion, Mobileye unit goodwill $8.3 billion (4.2% of assets) and a $2.6 billion impairment loss recorded.

The audit affirmed Intel’s effective internal control over financial reporting and issued an unqualified opinion on the 2024 financial statements. 2024 results show a sharp decline in net revenue to $53.1 billion (down from $54.4 billion in 2023 and $63.1 billion in 2022), a net loss of $19.2 billion versus a $1.7 billion profit in 2023, operating loss of $11.7 billion, and earnings per share of -$4.38.  Cash and cash equivalents fell to $8.25 billion, while total debt remained high at $46.3 billion.  The company’s cost structure shifted with lower R&D and SG&A spend but higher restructuring charges.  Share counts remained roughly flat around 4.28 billion shares.  Overall, the company moved from profitability in 2023 to a substantial loss in 2024, highlighting significant financial headwinds.

Operating cash flow fell sharply from 15433000 in 2022 to 11471000 in 2023 and 8288000 in 2024, reflecting a swing to a 19233 loss in 2024 after profits in prior years. Investing cash remained strongly negative each year due to large PPE additions and short‑term investment purchases. Financing cash turned positive in 2024, driven by partner contributions and long‑term debt issuance, while dividend payments continued. Cash balances recovered to 8249 at end of 2024.

Intel highlighted a change in accounting estimate effective January 2023 that extended the useful life of certain production equipment from 5 to 8 years, boosting 2023 gross margin by $2.5 billion, cutting R&D expense by $400 million and lowering ending inventory by $1.3 billion. The company noted that reclassifications made in 2024 had no effect on previously reported net income, cash flows or equity. Fiscal years 2024 and 2023 were 52‑week periods, 2022 a 53‑week year, and 2025 will revert to 52 weeks. Management reiterated revenue is recognized at shipment, described variable consideration and cooperative advertising offsets, and explained depreciation, capitalized interest and asset‑impairment assessment processes for long‑lived assets.

The company extended the estimated useful life of wafer fab machinery from 5 to 8 years starting Q1 2023, noted excess capacity charges of $174 M in 2024 (down from $834 M in 2023 and $423 M in 2022), and highlighted a single‑counterparty credit exposure cap of $1.4 B. It also disclosed that its three largest customers account for 47% of receivables.

Intel implemented an internal foundry operating model in Q1 2024, reorganizing segments (Altera moved to "all other") and aligning intersegment accounting. Total consolidated revenue was $53.1 billion, but the company recorded a consolidated operating loss of $11.7 billion, driven by a $13.4 billion loss in Intel Foundry and significant intersegment eliminations. Third‑party foundry revenue contributed $385 million. The segment restructuring and intersegment adjustments materially impact profitability and cash flow outlook.

Revenue declined from $63.1B in 2022 to $54.2B in 2023, compressing operating income sharply to $93M from $2.3B. Corporate unallocated expenses remain material, driven by share‑based compensation (~$3.4B in 2024) and restructuring charges. The top three customers still account for roughly 45% of net revenue, indicating concentration risk. Geographic revenue is broadly diversified, with China and the United States each contributing around $15B‑$13B annually.

Intel sold a 49% stake in Ireland SCIP to Apollo for $11.0 billion, triggering $755 million of 2024 loss from liquidated‑damage provisions and exposing up to $1.1 billion of further penalties if Fab 34 delays continue. Construction of Fab 34 remains delayed but Intel intends to complete it. Arizona SCIP construction costs are estimated at $29.0 billion, with $11.5 billion of assets as of Dec 2024. Intel converted and sold 38.5 million Mobileye shares, raising $1.6 billion and $663 million of capital. IMS Nanofabrication minority stakes were sold for $1.4 billion, adding $958 million of capital. Net loss widened to $19.2 billion in 2024, with a basic EPS loss of $4.38. Accounts receivable factoring totaled $2.3 billion in 2024 and inventories rose to $12.2 billion.

The company sold $2.3B of accounts receivable on a non‑recourse basis in 2024 (down from $2.0B in 2023), recorded $12.2B of inventory and grew net property, plant and equipment to $107.9B. Significant non‑cash charges included $2.3B of asset impairments and $992M of accelerated depreciation, plus $442M other impairments. Capital‑related government incentives reduced gross PPE by $9.5B and were recognized as $4.1B of reductions and $3.3B of non‑cash investing activity. The firm received up to $3.0B CHIPS Act funding, a $7.9B direct funding agreement, and recognized $1.3B of grants and a $2.6B tax credit in 2024. Operating‑related incentives boosted operating income by $442M. Advertising expense was $856M. Interest income rose to $1.245B while interest expense was $1.034B (net of $1.5B capitalized). Restructuring charges totaled $6.97B in 2024, with $2.48B employee severance and $3.63B asset impairments, bringing cumulative restructuring cost to $2.8B.

The company announced and began executing a $3.0 billion 2024 Restructuring Plan, with $2.8 billion incurred to date and $2.2 billion of employee severance costs plus $294 million of other operational cuts. Cumulative 2022 restructuring cost stands at $1.3 billion. Litigation costs include a $780 million charge in 2024 and a $401 million EC fine and $353 million termination fee in 2023, offset by $1.2 billion benefits in 2023 and 2022. Asset impairments are sizable: $442 million construction‑in‑progress, $103 million operating‑lease assets, $83 million other lease assets, $3.0 billion goodwill and $108 million intangible impairments in 2024. The tax provision rose sharply to $8.023 billion in 2024 (effective tax rate 71.6%), driven by valuation allowances and impairments, while tax holidays provided $67 million benefit. Deferred tax assets remain large ($10.709 billion R&D, $2.830 billion state credits) but are offset by a $13.974 billion valuation allowance, yielding net deferred tax assets of $‑859 million.

Valuation allowance for deferred tax assets rose sharply by $10.9 billion in 2024 due to US tax asset realizability uncertainty; federal and non‑US NOL carryforwards stand at $279 million and $2.7 billion, and foreign subsidiaries hold about $21 billion of undistributed earnings with no deferred tax recognized. Current tax receivable increased to $2.6 billion, while long‑term tax payable fell to $1.6 billion. Gross unrecognized tax benefits marginally rose to $1.13 billion, with a potential $946 million benefit if recognized and could drop up to $314 million in the next year. Marketable debt fair value fell to $13.5 billion (down from $17.1 billion) and hedged positions posted a $464 million loss. Equity investments contracted, with total $5.38 billion of marketable and non‑marketable holdings and net gains of $242 million. The company recorded a $4.6 billion cash gain from the McAfee sale and retains a $2.0 billion receivable from the NAND OpCo transaction, which also carries up to $500 million annual and $1.5 billion aggregate incentive/penalty exposure. Goodwill declined to $24.7 billion from $27.6 billion.

The company recorded a $2.8 billion non‑cash goodwill impairment in Q3 2024, primarily for Mobileye, bringing total accumulated impairment to $3.9 billion (Mobileye $2.6 billion, CCG $364 million, DCAI $275 million, NEX $79 million, other $582 million). A $222 million impairment was recognized in Q1 2024 for the Intel Foundry unit. Short‑term debt increased to $3.7 billion versus $2.3 billion a year earlier, while the board maintains a $10 billion commercial‑paper authorization with none outstanding. Licensed technology arrangements totaled $562 million in 2024 versus $309 million in 2023. Net identified intangible assets declined to $3.69 billion from $4.59 billion, and amortization expense fell to $1.43 billion in 2024 after $1.76 billion in 2023 and $1.91 billion in 2022. Future amortization is projected at $3.687 billion through 2029 and thereafter.

Short-term debt rose to $3.7 billion at year‑end 2024 from $2.3 billion in 2023, and the board authorizes up to $10 billion of commercial paper, with no paper outstanding. The firm holds a broad range of fixed‑rate senior notes maturing from 2024 through 2063, with individual issuances ranging from $500 million to $2.25 billion and interest rates between 1.60% and 5.90%.

2024 saw issuance of $2.6 billion senior notes and settlement of $1.9 billion, while 2023 issuance was $11 billion. The company remarketed $438 million of Arizona bonds in 2024 versus $423 million in 2023, and expanded its revolving credit facilities to $7 billion (5‑year) and $8 billion (364‑day) with extended maturities. No borrowings were outstanding on these facilities. Debt maturities are front‑loaded through 2030, totaling $50.985 billion, with the largest single‑year tranche $34.448 billion in 2030 and thereafter. Total long‑term debt stood at $46.282 billion at year‑end 2024, down from $46.978 billion in 2023.

The filing details fair‑value hierarchy classifications, noting grants receivable of $1.7 bn (2024) and $559 m (2023) as Level 2, and issued debt of $43.5 bn (2024) and $47.6 bn (2023) also Level 2. Derivative activity shows total notional of $45.96 bn in 2024 versus $50.53 bn in 2023, with foreign‑currency contracts at $25.5 bn and interest‑rate contracts at $17.9 bn in 2024. Pay‑variable receive‑fixed swaps total $12 bn. Hedging derivatives hold $40 m in assets and $987 m in liabilities (2024); non‑hedging derivatives hold $1.042 bn in assets and $880 m in liabilities (2024). Overall derivative fair‑value assets are $1.082 bn and liabilities $1.867 bn as of 2024.

Derivative assets total $948 million and liabilities $1,084 million as of Dec 28 2024 (up from $1,047 million and $1,111 million in 2023). Net cash‑flow hedge losses were $652 million in 2024 (vs a $3 million gain in 2023) and $910 million loss in 2022, with $205 million of losses excluded from effectiveness testing in 2024. Fair‑value hedge adjustments added $546 million to long‑term debt in 2024 and $36 million to short‑term debt. Non‑designated derivatives generated a $422 million net loss in 2024. An embedded derivative liability related to the Ireland SCIP agreement caused a $755 million loss in 2024. Supplemental deferred compensation balances increased to $3.3 billion, and matching contribution expenses rose to $541 million. The US Retiree Medical Plan showed projected obligations of $493 million against assets of $542 million, with discount rates of 5.7% and 5.3% for 2024 and 2023 respectively.

The US Retiree Medical Plan remained in a net‑asset position with projected benefit obligations of $493 M versus assets of $542 M at year‑end 2024, while the 2023 figures were $490 M vs $548 M. The plan follows a 50/50 equity‑fixed‑income target and uses primarily liquid, tax‑aware assets. Worldwide pension and retiree plans were 86% funded; net periodic benefit cost fell to $69 M in 2024 from $107 M in 2023. Several pension plans show unfunded status, with accumulated benefit obligations exceeding assets in some non‑US plans. Discount rates for pension assumptions were modestly lower in 2024 (4.6% vs 4.5% in 2023) and the US pension asset mix targets 91% fixed income/9% equity.

The company’s US pension plan targets a 91% fixed‑income/9% equity mix, while non‑US plans aim for 50% fixed income, 35% equity and 15% hedge funds in 2024. Estimated benefit payments over the next decade total roughly $1.1 billion, with the largest single‑year outflow of $623 million in 2030‑34. The 2006 equity incentive plan authorizes 1.1 billion shares, with 171 million remaining, and 10 million performance units are outstanding. Share‑based compensation was $3.4 billion in 2024, generating a $684 million tax benefit and a $139 million tax expense. RSU/PSU fair‑value assumptions include a 4.7% risk‑free rate, 1.2% dividend yield and 36% volatility. Stock‑unit balances fell from 172.9 million to 117.4 million in 2024, with 64.5 million granted and 104.3 million expected to vest. The ESPP authorized 523 million shares, with 118 million remaining; employees bought 39 million shares for $972 million in 2024. Operating lease assets stand at $457 million with $248 million lease expense, and finance‑lease assets are $470 million; total lease payments through 2029 amount to $687 million and present‑value $614 million. Capital‑expenditure commitments dropped to $20 billion, other purchase obligations to $7 billion, and an unfunded SCIP contribution of $10.5 billion remains. Legal provisions include a $1 billion VLSI charge, a $401 million EC fine, and a $780 million restructuring charge in Q2 2024. The prior €1.1 billion EC fine from 2009 was overturned in 2022.

Intel continues to face extensive litigation, including a historic €1.1 billion EU fine paid in 2009 and a new €376 million fine imposed in 2023 that is under appeal. The company settled EC default‑interest claims for €516 million in 2024 and received $484 million insurance proceeds for a 2020 facility outage. Major patent disputes with VLSI have produced jury awards of $1.5 billion, $675 million, $2.2 billion total damages and $162 million interest, while a separate Texas case sought $3 billion and another awarded $949 million. Intel has accrued a $1 billion charge for VLSI litigation and expects to pay $780 million to resolve R2 Semiconductor disputes. Multiple securities and derivative class actions remain pending with no loss estimates available.

Intel resolved pending European injunction and related litigation by entering three confidential agreements in August 2024, committing to an aggregate $780 million payment, while also recognizing $484 million of business interruption insurance proceeds from a 2020 facility outage, offsetting cost of sales.

Management affirmed that disclosure controls and internal control over financial reporting were effective as of December 28, 2024, with no material changes during the quarter, and Ernst & Young independently confirmed this assessment.

Intel filed multiple supplemental indenture documents (exhibits 4.11‑4.19) from 2017 to 2024, updating its debt agreements with Wells Fargo and later Computershare as trustees, and refreshed its 2006 Equity Incentive Plan with recent grant filings in 2023.

Intel's supplemental filing lists numerous exhibits covering RSU grant agreements, retirement plan amendments, indemnification agreements, settlement and purchase agreements, and related amendment letters filed between 2020 and 2024, indicating ongoing governance, compensation, and structural activities.
Exhibit list and cross‑reference index detailing filing dates and document types; no substantive operational or financial information provided.
